messageBody:
Good point, I hadn't thought about word shape.

I'd say that abbreviations were better in that regard than a fully
written out word.
An abbreviation's letters, and therefore shape, are fixed regardless of
the author's dialect.
Admittedly, since all the abbreviations are for short words there isn't
much room for variation to creep in so they aren't as useful as they
could be.

I would imagine that if QS were to go main stream standard spellings
would be created.
National and regional standards for official publications and education.
House styles for individual companies and businesses.
And individuals would just use their own dialect for emails/letters/etc.

John Cowan wrote:
>
> amd64_hacker scripsit:
>
> > Personally I'm for abbreviations in all texts.
> > It seems to me that since QS is meant to be 'heard' it shouldn't matter
> > how the word is written but how it is read.
>
> Well, yes, but that slows down reading to the speed of speech. I suspect
> that rapid silent reading and standardized orthography go together --
> we do know that fluent readers recognize familiar words by the total
> shape of the word, slowing down only when they must to read an unfamilar
> word, and that this is equally true in languages that are rationally
> spelled, irrationally spelled, or not spelled at all (like Chinese).
>
> So if QS is going to become important for works meant to be read
> more than once (as opposed to shorthand/transcription uses), a
> standardized orthography will have to evolve.
>
> Which immediately leads to the issue of dialects. One's obvious and
> natural phonetic orthography is another's stumbling block. ("Hmm,
> is it spelled 'theft' or 'feft'?" "Hmm, does this mean 'lord' or
> 'laud'?") A universal orthography ends up needing to make more
> distinctions
> than any one dialect actually needs, and thus to some extent becoming
> artificial to all.
>
> --
> John Cowan cowan@... <mailto:cowan%40ccil.org>
> "Mr. Lane, if you ever wish anything that I can do, all you will have
> to do will be to send me a telegram asking and it will be done."
> "Mr. Hearst, if you ever get a telegram from me asking you to do
> anything, you can put the telegram down as a forgery."
>
>
